legendaryGroup.name: Infested Dragon
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Part of the ceiling collapses above one creature that the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone} and buried. The buried target is {@condition restrained} and unable to breathe or stand up. A creature can take an action to make a {@dc 10} Strength check, ending the buried state on a success.

Giant, wriggling worms erupt from the ground, grasping at creatures in a 20-foot radius centered on a point that the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. That area becomes difficult terrain, and each creature that starts its turn in the area or enters it on its turn must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} by the worms. A creature can be freed if it or another creature takes an action to make a {@dc 15} Strength check and succeeds. The worms recede when the dragon uses this lair action again or when the dragon dies.

A wave of energy sweeps inward, rushing toward the dragon and pulling creatures along with it. Each creature within 120 feet of the dragon must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage of the type selected for the dragon's damage immunity (acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison) and is swept 20 feet closer to the dragon. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and is not moved.

regionalEffects: The region containing a legendary infected dragon's lair is warped by the dragon's corrupted magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Hidden sinkholes form in and around the dragon's lair. A sinkhole can be spotted from a safe distance with a successful {@dc 20} Wisdom (Perception) check. Otherwise, the first creature to step on the thin crust covering the sinkhole must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or fall {@dice 1d6 Ã— 10} feet into the sinkhole.
Within 1 mile of its lair, the dragon leaves no physical evidence of its passage unless it wishes to. Tracking it there is impossible except by magical means.

The soil within 6 miles of the dragon's lair is filled with an unnatural number of worms, which burrow under the surface and cause the ground to very slowly undulate. Worms within 1 mile of the dragon's lair serve as the dragon's eyes and ears. Deer and other large game are strangely absent, hinting at the presence of an unnaturally hungry predator.

regionalEffects: If the dragon dies, the worms lose their supernatural link to it. The population of worms in the area returns to a normal amount in approximately one month. Any sinkholes remain where they are.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the fire slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 fire damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The fire slug can breathe air and water.

action.name: Cerata
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1  fire damage.

action.name: Cnidosac
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1  poison damage.

reaction.name: Toxic Mucus {@recharge 4}
entries: When the fire slug is hit with a melee attack, or when a creature attempts to grapple it, the fire slug can exude toxic mucus from its skin. The mucus coats the fire slug, and lasts until the start of its next turn. While the mucus is present, a creature that touches the fire slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it (including the triggering melee attack) must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take 1 poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. While active, the mucus coating cools the slug's fiery body somewhat, suppressing the effects of Heated Body.

There are many animals you shouldn't step on at the beach. A sea urchin or stingray will leave you with venom-filled puncture wounds, while a jellyfish will inject a particularly nasty toxic cocktail. Step on a fire slug, however, and you will soon find your feet covered in burns and blisters.

Through an unknown process, these odd sea slugs produce intense heat. The reason for this is also uncertain, since, like many sea slugs, fire slugs are usually passive creatures, content to graze on seaweed and corals on reefs and near the shore.  However, when threatened, they have a slew of defensive abilities to protect their otherwise soft and vulnerable bodies. In addition to the extreme temperature they emit, their bodies are covered in special tentacles called cerata, which jet tiny flames from their tips. They also possess modified cerata with poison bulbs called cnidosacs on the ends. These tentacles, along with a toxic mucus coating, compensate for the slug's slow speed and squishy body.

If you encounter one of these stunning creatures, it is best to admire its beauty from a distance; a fire slug's defenses are always active, and they are unsuitable for use as either pets or food. Some have tried to keep them in aquaria, but they have a reputation for melting through the glass or boiling other inhabitants alive, and their flesh is chewy and poisonous to most creatures.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The giant fire slug can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the giant fire slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage.

action.name: Cerata
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 9 ({@damage 2d8}) bludgeoning damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Cnidosac
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

reaction.name: Toxic Mucus {@recharge 4}
entries: When the fire slug is hit with a melee attack, or when a creature attempts to grapple it, the fire slug can exude toxic mucus from its skin. For the next minute, the mucus coats the fire slug. While the mucus is present, a creature that touches the fire slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it (including the triggering melee attack) must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. While active, the mucus coating cools the slug's fiery body somewhat, suppressing the effects of Heated Body.

When the giant fire slug takes this reaction, excess mucus pools in its space. This pool remains in the space for 1 minute, even if the slug moves to a different space. A creature moving into this space must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the creature must succeed on the same {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage.

If the slug is underwater, the excess mucus instead spreads into the water around it. When this reaction is taken, every creature in a space adjacent to the giant fire slug must make the associated Constitution saving throw.

Giant fire slugs, like many giant versions of creatures, are the subject of quite a bit of controversy in academic circles. Some scholars believe that they are the result of intentional or accidental magical modification. Others, especially certain circles of coastal druids, hold that these creatures have lived alongside their smaller relatives for millennia, and that they are an odd but perfectly natural part of the ecosystem.

The danger that giant fire slugs pose is much more certain than their origins. Though they share the general passive nature of regular fire slugs, they are easier to provoke. Even when they are not being aggressive, giant fire slugs are a hazard for coastal towns and fishing villages. Between the intense heat they produce and the toxic trail of mucus they leave, these creatures can do considerable damage to wooden structures, crops, livestock, and people. If it decides to search a settlement for food, a single unchecked fire slug can render significant sections uninhabitable for days or weeks, until the fires die down and the soil recovers from the toxic mucus.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the volcano slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 fire damage.

trait.name: Lava Skimmer
entries: The volcano slug can move along the surface of lava or briefly dip below the surface without being burned. It can spend up to 2 turns on the surface of lava, and can use its burrowing speed to swim under the surface for a single turn. Once it has used this trait, it must spend {@dice 1d4} turns out of lava before it is cool enough to use this trait again.

action.name: Cerata
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1  piercing damage.

action.name: Cnidosac
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1  poison damage.

reaction.name: Toxic Mucus {@recharge 4}
entries: When the volcano slug is hit with a melee attack, or when a creature attempts to grapple it, the fire slug can exude toxic mucus from its skin. The mucus coats the volcano slug, and lasts until the start of its next turn. While the mucus is present, a creature that touches the volcano slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it (including the triggering melee attack) must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take 1 poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. While active, the mucus coating cools the slug's molten body somewhat, suppressing the effects of Heated Body.

Volcano slugs are close relatives of fire slugs. Unlike their coastal cousins, these creatures live on and in volcanic soil, and are especially abundant around active volcanoes and lava flows. They are hardier than fire slugs, and have increased defense from the spiky crust of dried lava that covers their backs.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the giant volcano slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage.

trait.name: Crumbling Armor
entries: If the giant volcano slug takes more than 10 bludgeoning damage (after resistance) in a single turn, its protective rocky coating crumbles, reducing the slug's AC to 9. The coating reforms after the slug has spent {@dice 1d4 + 3} days near active volcanoes or lava flows.

trait.name: Lava Skimmer
entries: The giant volcano slug can move along the surface of lava or briefly dip below the surface without being burned. It can spend up to 4 turns on the surface of lava, and can use its burrowing speed to swim under the surface for a single turn. After this time, it may still move on or through the lava, but it takes {@damage 5d6} fire damage at the start of each of its turns. Once it has used this trait, it must spend {@dice 1d4 + 3} turns out of lava before it is cool enough to use this trait again.

action.name: Cerata
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 9 ({@damage 2d8}) bludgeoning damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Cnidosac
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

reaction.name: Toxic Mucus {@recharge 4}
entries: When the volcano slug is hit with a melee attack, or when a creature attempts to grapple it, the volcano slug can exude toxic mucus from its skin. For the next minute, the mucus coats the volcano slug. While the mucus is present, a creature that touches the volcano slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it (including the triggering melee attack) must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. While active, the mucus coating cools the slug's molten body somewhat, suppressing the effects of Heated Body.

When the giant volcano slug takes this reaction, excess mucus pools in its space. This pool remains in the space for 1 minute, even if the slug moves to a different space. A creature moving into this space must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the creature must succeed on the same {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage.

If any part of the slug's space or an adjacent space contains lava when it takes this reaction, the mucus pool instead catches fire. A creature moving into this space must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage on a failure, or half damage on a success. The pool burns for 3 rounds.

Giant volcano slugs share the same temperament as giant fire slugs. Unlike giant fire slugs, however, their cerata are crusted over with jagged shards of cooled lava that splinter and pierce on impact.

trait.name: Hop
entries: The abyssal zonathid can use all its movement on a turn to magically propel itself 10 feet through the air before silently landing. This movement can be parallel to the ground, or may be used to jump up or down to a surface.

trait.name: Tactical Eyebeams
entries: The abyssal zonathid can use its Eyebeam attack offensively, but its main use is accessing the flesh of its prey. Using Eyebeam to deal acid damage melts away a small hole in most nonliving materials, including metal, wood, cloth, and leather. The necrotic Eyebeam, on the other hand, is used to eat through its prey's natural defenses, such as armored hide or protective mucus, to reach the flesh underneath. Once it has reached its prey's flesh, the zonathid uses the poison Eyebeam to numb the immediate area while it settles in to feed. A creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw to resist the numbing and notice the zonathid. A creature has advantage on this saving throw if it is resistant to poison damage, and automatically succeeds if it is immune to poison damage.

trait.name: Vigilant
entries: The abyssal zonathid cannot be surprised.

action.name: Eyebeam
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 0} to hit, range 10 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic, poison, or acid damage.

action.name: Adhere
entries: The abyssal zonathid positions itself above an open wound on its victim. It secretes a biological glue that adheres it to the victim's skin. If the victim is unaware of the zonathid's presence, it must make a {@dc 17} Constitution save. On a failure, it remains unaware of the abyssal zonathid, and the wound and surrounding skin are numbed for {@dice 1d4 + 3} days. See the zonathid's description for long-term effects. On a success, the creature becomes aware of the zonathid's presence, and may use its reaction to pull the zonathid off the wound.

bonus.name: Hide
entries: The abyssal zonathid takes the Hide action.

\"While the exact nature of an abyssal zonathid's creation remains unclear, I have found similarities to the body plan of beholders. While the eye slits at the end of each stalk belie none of the intelligence of a true beholder, each slit is capable of projecting a weak beam of magic, to various effects. It also seems that their ability to leap through the air stems from a similar organ to the one beholders use to fly and hover.\"
-Dhornii Fleckeri, gnomish druid and zoologist

The abyssal zonathid is a pathetic creature, limply crawling in the dank recesses of caves and other perpetually dark places. Its body is a jumbled mess of short, stocky eyestalks, each eyestalk having a narrow, slitted eye at its end. In the center its body is a large pink tongue, surrounded by a circle of tiny red tentacles, which writhe about in an unnerving fashion.

A typical abyssal zonathid is only a couple inches across, and even when encountered in groups, it poses no significant threat to the most inexperienced fighter. While slightly hardier than its size and flaccid, fleshy appearance would suggest, it has neither extraordinary weapons nor developed defenses.

However, abyssal zonathids are only easy to kill if they are noticed, and they will go to great lengths to avoid attention. These tiny aberrations are parasites, and they prefer to prey on unaware humanoids. Their favorite hunting strategy is to hide in a cave, sewer, dungeon, or other place that is simultaneously out of the way and relatively well-traveled. When a hunting party, guard patrol, or group of adventurers sets up camp near their hiding spots, they prepare to strike. An abyssal zonathid will use its natural stealth and climbing ability to sneak up on a sleeping humanoid, preferring one whose back is easily accessible.

The zonathid will use its acid eyebeam to melt through clothing and armor, and its necrotic eyebeam to rapidly decay skin, scales, and other natural barriers between it and the humanoid's flesh, using its poison eyebeam as necessary to numb the wound before the victim can notice. Once it has opened a shallow wound (typically 2-3 centimeters wide), it positions its \"mouth\" above the wound, and presses down. It secretes an adhesive numbing agent that both glues its body to the skin of the victim, and numbs the area. While the numbing from its poison eyebeam is relatively short-lived, the anesthetic qualities of this mucus are much stronger. If the victim humanoid does not notice the mucus (see the saving throw for its Adhere action), the wound and surrounding area will remain numb for {@dice 1d4+3} days.

If it successfully adheres to its victim, the abyssal zonathid proceeds to its feeding stage. First, it inserts its oral tentacles into blood vessels exposed by the wound. These tentacles siphon blood from the host, providing both sustenance and information. Once it has begun absorbing blood from its victim, the zonathid will change appearance, taking on the color and texture of the victim's skin. It becomes very difficult to notice, appearing only as a slightly raised bump on the skin (this bump can be between 2-4 inches wide). At this point, especially if it has chosen an area on its host's back, the zonathid may remain undetected for weeks.

Once it has fully connected to the host's bloodstream and camouflaged itself, the abyssal zonathid begins its secondary feeding behavior. Though it is unkown exactly why, the creature will use its large central tongue to lap at the open wound, keeping it just irritated enough to prevent healing. While the numbing effects of the mucus last, this licking is undetectable. Even after the mucus has worn off, the host will be unable to pinpoint the sensation, feeling only a general discomfort and uneasiness. Explicitly focusing on this sensation and succeeding a DC 15 Perception check will allow a victim to localize this feeling to a specific part of the body, though it will not specifically reveal the zonathid.

If the zonathid remains attached to a host for more than 2 weeks, the host's maximum hit points are reduced by {@dice 1d4}, and this effect increases by {@dice 1d4} for every 2 successive weeks. Additionally, each month the abyssal zonathid remains attached, the victim gains a level of exhaustion, which does not fade until the zonathid is removed.

Removing an abyssal zonathid from its host is non-trivial. Attempting to pull or scrape it off, or remove it by some other means, is ill advised; when disrupted or injured, the zonathid releases chemicals that powerfully stimulate the host's nervous system, causing intense pain and convulsions. If it is killed while attached to a host (if the host has not already died from shock and muscle spasms), it releases potent toxins into the host's bloodstream, dealing {@dice 3d4} poison damage and poisoning the victim. A creature that has been poisoned in this way remains poisoned until healed by the effects of {@spell Lesser Restoration} or another spell or effect that cures diseases and conditions. The dead zonathid must also be removed from the wound and its oral tentacles extracted, which usually involves cutting off some of the host's skin, unless a method of dissolving the adhesive mucus can be found.

An abyssal zonathid may be successfully removed without poisoning its host if it is dealt twice its maximum HP in radiant damage in one round, or if the spell {@spell Lesser Restoration} or a similar spell is cast on it.

trait.name: Dehydrated Detonation
entries: If the urchin is left out of water for {@dice 1d4 + 3} hours (or {@dice 1d4} hours in sunlight), or set on fire, it becomes too dehydrated to hold itself together, and explodes. Each creature in a 5 ft. radius of the urchin must make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the creature is subject to the effects of Venomous Spines. If more than 1 urchin explodes simultaneously, the DC increases to 15.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The urchin can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Venomous Spines
entries: If a creature handles the urchin with bare skin (or fails the saving throw from Dehydrated Detonation), it must make a {@dc 5} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 1 piercing damage and 1 poison damage. If the creature rolls a natural 1, it fails the saving throw and suffers a heart attack, taking 4 levels of {@condition exhaustion} and falling {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Pincushion
entries: If a creature is subject to the effects of Venomous Spines multiple times simultaneously, the DC for the Constitution saving throw increases by 1 for every additional activation, up to a DC of 30. On the 5th additional activation ({@dc 10}), the heart attack range increases by 1. This pattern continues for every 5 additional activations (e.g. at 15 additional activations, DC is 20 and a roll of 1-4 triggers a heart attack), even if the maximum DC has already been reached.

"There was a sudden unidentifiable sound, loud, and followed by a rain of small, sharp spines. Our local guide informed us that the explosion was the result of a dehydrated acanthar urchin, likely one that had been launched out of its spring by a geyser. The sound is difficult to describe; somewhere between the pop of a balloon and the crunch of dry leaves."
-Dhornii Fleckeri, gnomish druid and zoologist

The acanthar urchin is a creature full of irregular, contradictory properties. Their venom is usually no more dangerous than a bee sting, but about 5% of victims suffer sudden cardiac arrest. Though quite sturdy for their size, if left out of water for too long, they destabilize in spectacular fashion, suddenly exploding and releasing a shower of venomous spines. Finally, as a seeming rebellion against their toxic nature, the innards of acanthar urchins can be used to produce a soothing salve, useful for treating skin irritation and contact poisons.

Their odd idiosyncrasies don't stop with their physical features; while they can be found in shallow ocean waters like many other urchins, acanthar urchins are more common in sulfurous springs. It is still unknown how these creatures survive in such extreme conditions, or how they even reach such springs in the first place. Some theories suggest that the urchins release spores when they explode, hoping that at least a few reach a new body of water. Conversely, it is the belief of certain druidic circles that most acanthar urchins live in massive populations deep under the earth, and that the specimens found in sulfur springs are those few individuals that have floated to the surface. These druids also hold that acanthar urchins play a vital role in natural energy cycles.

For adventurers, however, the usefulness of the acanthar urchin in setting traps is much more interesting than its ecology. The urchins may be used as fire-activated grenades or mines. The cumulative effects of their venom mean that even a small pile of urchins can be turned into a dangerous explosive trap with little more than a torch or some lamp oil.
Poisons and Salves
The acanthar urchin can be harvested to produce both a poison and a salve.

- Poison. To produce a useful poison from acanthar venom, the spines must be harvested. A single vial requires the spines of {@dice 1d4+1} urchins; these spines must be boiled in water from a sulfur spring for at least 1 hour.

The poison only works if dispersed in a creature's bloodstream; this can be accomplished by coating a piercing or slashing weapon, or injecting the poison with a syringe. The poison lasts for 4 attacks when coating a weapon.

A creature affected by the poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes {@dice 2d4} poison damage and is poisoned until the end of its next turn (if inflicted by a weapon) or for 1 hour (if injected with a syringe). Furthermore, if the result of the saving throw is less than 8 (or a natural 1), the creature suffers a heart attack, taking 4 levels of exhaustion and falling unconscious.

- Salve. The innards of acanthar urchins can be used to make a soothing salve. To access the innards, the urchins must be cracked open, taking care not to contaminate the organs with the venom in the spines. A single dose requires the innards from {@dice 1d4} urchins. The gooey mass of tissues must then be thoroughly mixed with half a liter of lotion, gel, or other skin-safe viscous fluid.

One dose of salve is enough to treat one limb or half the torso of a medium creature, or two limbs or the entire torso of a small creature. When applied to the skin of a creature, the salve fully soothes skin irritation and inflammation, such as that caused by poison ivy or bug bites. Additionally, if applied to skin affected by a contact poison within 10 minutes of exposure, the salve will cure a creature of the effects of the poison, including removing the poisoned condition (it does not heal any damage or undo effects that have already applied).
Certain exotic or magical poisons may be too strong to be healed by this salve; don't treat it as an excuse to pour strange liquids on your skin (or your friends' skins).

monster.name: Deepstar
senses: blindsight 120 ft. (blind beyond this radius except for the effects of Phototaxis)

trait.name: Bioluminescence
entries: The deepstar emits dim light in a 5-foot radius, and can flash as a free action to briefly emit bright light in a 10-foot radius.

trait.name: Offensive Defense
entries: When a creature touches the deepstar or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or take 1 piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage. As long as physical contact is sustained, the creature must make this save again at the start of its turn. These effects persist for {@dice 1d4} hours after the deepstar dies.

trait.name: Ephemeral
entries: The deepstar can't wear or carry anything.

trait.name: Phototaxis
entries: The deepstar can perceive sources of bright light within 240 feet, and dim light within 120 feet. It is immediately aware of sources of light within these ranges if they are not concealed. The deepstar is attracted to sources of light at night, and avoids sources of light during the day.

trait.name: Pyrophobia
entries: The deepstar is afraid of fire, and avoids any source of fire it can perceive. Creatures carrying a source of fire, or who have used fire magic in the presence of the deepstar within the past 10 minutes, have disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks and advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks against the deepstar.

action.name: Nematocyst
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} {@damage 1} piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Sparklespores
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +3} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) lightning damage.

reaction.name: Singed Panic
entries: If the deepstar takes fire damage that does not reduce it to 0 hit points, it panics. It immediately moves up to its speed away from the object or creature that dealt the fire damage. Attacks against the deepstar have disadvantage for the duration of this movement and until the start of its next turn, as it flies erratically and unpredictably. On its next turn, it uses its action to summon help, being joined by other deepstars and becoming a deepstar swarm.

"Deepstars have stingers covering the entire surface of their tentacles. Regardless of how friendly they may be, it is advisable to refrain from touching them. The sparklespores they emit also give a light jolt of electricity when touched. A couple on their own don't hurt any more than accidentally shocking yourself with static, but a heavy cloud of spores can be dangerous. Moreover, the deepstars seem to have some control over the movement of these spores. I dread to think of the effects if an enraged swarm decided to use them offensively."
-Kriftik Kreftwyn, Artificer of the Tinkers Arcanic Gnomica

Deepstars can be found wherever fae magic pervades a natural area, such as a forest or cave. They emit a soft glow, and are serene creatures, almost mesmerizing to watch as they float through the air with their characteristic erratic pulsing. These tiny fey appear as an odd mix between mushrooms and jellyfish. At rest, they settle on forest and cave floors, as well as tree trunks and cave walls and ceilings, and in this state can easily be mistaken for glowing mushrooms. This misidentification is easily realized when they are disturbed, detaching from surfaces and drifting about, the stalks of these \"mushrooms\" unfolding to reveal a set of tiny tentacles.

One peculiarity of deepstar biology is their multiple sets of eyes, arranged in a circle around the edge of their bodies. This allows a full 360-degree horizontal range of vision. Their eyes are not very sophisticated, and they can only see within a small radius. They are, however, very sensitive to light, and seem to be able to detect light sources well outside their normal range of vision.

Deepstars are good by nature. While they have a spooky, otherworldly appearance, they are often regarded as omens of good fortune and harmony with nature. Unlike many fey, deepstars are neither shy nor reclusive.

Swarmkeeper rangers from areas affected by fae magic, or with some connection to the Feywild, often choose deepstars as their swarm creature. Additionally, if provided with a steady supply of plant matter, they can be convinced to reside in almost any building or area; some people put them in special lanterns, both to provide light and as good luck charms. However, deepstars avoid light during the day, so these lanterns must be covered before the sun rises to avoid distressing them.

While they are generally peaceful and friendly, there are two things that a deepstar cannot tolerate. The first is damage to the natural world; deepstars will quickly abandon an area that unsustainably exploits natural resources. If forced to stay in these areas, they become agitated, and will become aggressive if not set free quickly.

The other deep-seated aversion that deepstars have is toward fire. These fey are especially vulnerable to burning, and they avoid fire at all costs. If a deepstar is burned by fire, it becomes panicked, and if the burn was inflicted by a creature, it enters a rage, calling other deepstars to its aid and becoming a much more aggressive and dangerous deepstar swarm. Though it is technically possible to calm down such a swarm and convince it to disperse, those experienced with these creatures know that this is a difficult and potentially deadly endeavor.
Poisonous Creatures

Deepstars are naturally poisonous. If a creature tries to eat one, it takes 3 magical piercing damage and 5 poison damage, and must make a DC 14 Constitution save to avoid spitting out the deepstar. A creature can choose to fail this save. If a creature swallows the deepstar, it takes another 5 magical piercing damage, and must make a DC 17 Constitution save or take 10 poison damage and be poisoned for {@dice 1d4} hours.

Deepstars can be used to make a unique poison. To make one vial of deepstar poision, {@dice 1d4+2} deepstars must be mixed with water from the area where the deepstars were found, as well as embalming fluid. This mixture must be agitated in such a way that the deepstars break apart into small pieces. (Embalming fluid can be bought from any establishment that has a cemetery, or from a temple associated with a god of death. One vial of embalming fluid is worth 5 gp.)
Item: Deepstar Poison (Contact, Ingested, or Injury).

If this poison comes into contact with a creature's bare skin, the creature takes {@dice 1d4+1} magical piercing damage and must make a DC 13 Constitution save, taking {@dice 1d4+4} poison damage and becoming poisoned for {@dice 1d4} rounds on a failure, or taking half damage on a success. Until/unless the poison is washed off, it can reapply this effect {@dice 1d4} times to any creature that touches the affected area with bare skin. A vial of deepstar poison can be used to inflict the above effects in the same manner as a vial of acid, detailed on page 148 of the PHB.
If consumed on its own, this poison has the same effect as attempting to eat a deepstar, though the DC for the saves is reduced to 12 and 15, respectively.

The poison can also be applied to food, drink, a weapon, or 3 ({@dice 1d4+1}) pieces of ammunition. Deepstar poison used in this manner retains its potency for 1 hour in food and drink (unless it is boiled, roasted, baked, etc. after being applied), or for 10 minutes on ammunition or a weapon.

If a creature consumes such poisoned food or drink, it takes 1 magical piercing damage and must make a DC 15 Constitution save. On a failure, it takes {@dice 1d4+3} poison damage and is poisoned for {@dice 1d4} hours. On a success, it takes half damage and is not poisoned.

If a creature is hit by an attack with a weapon or ammunition treated with deepstar poison, it takes an additional 3 ({@dice 1d4+1}) magical piercing damage. The creature must make a DC 15 Constitution save, taking 10 ({@dice 2d4+4}) poison damage and becoming poisoned for {@dice 1d4} rounds on a failure, or taking half damage on a success. These effects can be applied once by poisoned ammunition and 3 ({@dice 1d4+1}) times by a poisoned weapon. If a single creature is hit multiple times by a weapon or ammunition coated in deepstar poison, the duration of the poisoned condition afflicted is added to the duration left from previous hits.
If a weapon or ammunition inflicts fire damage while coated with deepstar poison, the poison is burned up and no longer coats the weapon.

trait.name: Bioluminescence
entries: The deepstar swarm emits bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet. It can flash as a free action, briefly increasing the radius of both the bright and dim light to 10 feet.

trait.name: Offensive Defense
entries: When a creature touches the deepstar swarm or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, or while the swarm occupies a creature's space, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage and 5 ({@damage 2d4}) poison damage.
As long as physical contact is sustained, the creature must make this save again at the start of its turn. These effects persist for {@dice 1d4} hours after the deepstar swarm is killed.

trait.name: Ephemeral
entries: The deepstar swarm can't wear or carry anything.

trait.name: Scorched Rage
entries: If a creature was responsible for the fire damage that triggered the original deepstar's Singed Panic, the deepstar swarm focuses its attacks on that creature. It has advantage on saving throws to avoid being {@condition frightened} by the focused creature. If another creature makes fire through mundane or magical means, it switches its focus to that creature. The subject of the swarm's focus and any other creature carrying fire have disadvantage on Charisma (Intimidation and Persusion) checks against the swarm.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny deepstar. The swarm can't regain hit points, except from Saprophytic Bloom, or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deepstar swarm makes two attacks using any combination of Nematocysts and Sparklespores.

action.name: Saprophytic Bloom {@recharge 5}
entries: The deepstar swarm can make a Nematocysts attack against each creature of its choice in its space and within 5 feet of it. For each creature hit, it regains 2 ({@dice 1d4}) hit point(s).

action.name: Sparklespores
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) lightning damage.

action.name: Nematocysts
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage and 5 ({@damage 2d4}) poison damage.

variant.name: Different Size Swarms
entries: Swarms of deepstars can be modified to Small or Large sizes.

-Small. To get the stats for a Small swarm, reduce the hit points to 35 ({@dice 10d6}), increase the Dex to 22 (+6) and the AC to 16, and decrease the Str to 3 (-4). Decrease the hit bonus of Sparklespores to +4, decrease the damage of Nematocysts to 2 piercing and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage, and decrease the damage of Sparklespores to 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage. Reduce the CR to 1 (200 XP)

-Large. To get the stats for a Large swarm, increase the hit points to 72 ({@dice 13d10}), decrease the Dex to 18 (+4) and the AC to 14, and increase the Str to 7 (-2). Increase the damage of Nematocysts to 5 ({@dice 1d10}) piercing and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage, and icrease the damage of Sparklespores to 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage. Increase Multiattack to three attacks. Increase the CR to 5 (1,800 XP).
See the info in the Deepstar entry

trait.name: Bioluminescence
entries: The corrupted deepstar swarm emits bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet. It can flash as a free action, briefly increasing the radius of both the bright and dim light to 10 feet.

trait.name: Into the Fire
entries: While corrupted deepstars are no longer vulnerable to flames, they are just as flammable as normal deepstars. When the corupted deepstar swarm takes fire damage, it bursts into flame. Whenever it deals damage in this state, including with Offensive Defense, it deals an additional 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage, and even on a successful saving throw, Offensive Defense deals 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage. It takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns while it is aflame.
The flames also emit bright light for 40 feet and dim light for an additional 40 feet.

This effect lasts for 1 round per 5 hit points that the swarm had when it took the triggering fire damage. This effect ends early if the swarm takes 8 cold damage in one round or is doused with or submerged in at least 15 gallons of water in one turn.

trait.name: Ephemeral
entries: The corrupted deepstar swarm can't wear or carry anything.

trait.name: Offensive Defense
entries: When a creature touches the corrupted deepstar swarm or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, or while the swarm occupies a creature's space, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. As long as physical contact is sustained, the creature must make this save again at the start of its turn. These effects persist for {@dice 1d4} hours after the corrupted deepstar swarm is killed.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny corrupted deepstar. The swarm can't regain hit points, except from Saprophytic Bloom, or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The corrupted deepstar swarm makes two attacks using any combination of Nematocysts and Sparklespores.

action.name: Saprophytic Bloom {@recharge 5}
entries: The deepstar swarm can make a Nematocysts attack against each creature of its choice in its space and within 5 feet of it. For each creature hit, it regains 2 ({@dice 1d4}) hit point(s).

action.name: Nematocyst
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Sparklespores
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) lightning damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage.

variant.name: Different Size Swarms
entries: Swarms of corrupted deepstars can be modified to Small or Large sizes.

-Small. To get the stats for a Small swarm, reduce the hit points to 45 ({@dice 10d6 + 10}), increase the Dex to 22 (+6) and the AC to 16, and decrease the Str to 5 (-3). Decrease the hit bonus of Sparklespores to +4, decrease the damage of Nematocysts to 3 ({@dice 1d6}) piercing and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage, and decrease the damage of Sparklespores to 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage. Reduce the CR to 2 (450 XP)

-Large. To get the stats for a Large swarm, increase the hit points to 85 ({@dice 13d10 + 13}), decrease the Dex to 18 (+4) and the AC to 14, and increase the Str to 9 (-1). Increase the damage of Nematocysts to 6 ({@dice 1d12}) piercing and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage, and icrease the damage of Sparklespores to 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage. Increase Multiattack to three attacks. Increase the CR to 6 (2,300 XP).

Deepstars are generally good creatures. They are gentle natured and friendly. They are dangerous only when they swarm, and they only swarm in response to fire. This is both a survival mechanism to compensate for their natural flammability, and a result of their desire to protect nature. During natural forest fires, deepstar swarms help guide and corral frightened creatures to safe caves and burrows, though the swarm will still panic if it catches fire itself. Generally, sighting a deepstar is considered a sign of good luck.

However, in areas ravaged by certain natural disasters (such as extreme fires or volcanic eruptions), or more commonly, industrial progress, a much more dangerous and malicious form of the deepstar may be found. In these areas where they are left with no more nature to retreat to or defend, deepstars go mad. Their innate drive to protect nature is twisted into a manic aggression toward any creature potentially responsible for the destruction of their home.

Corrupted deepstars, as they are known, are never encountered alone. They roam the desolate remains of their sanctuary in enraged swarms, attacking humanoids and nonnative creatures on sight. In addition to the damage to their psyches, corrupted deepstars suffer physical changes when they are deprived of nature. They lose the ability to produce poison, as well as their characteristic susceptibility to flames. While they are still flammable, it is ill advised to attempt to use fire against a corrupted deepstar swarm, since they will burst into flames and become even more dangerous.
Some druids, wizards, and other scholars have captured individuals from such swarms in an attempt to find a way to reverse their corruption, but none have yet succeeded.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The incense slug can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Divine Sense
entries: The incense slug is attracted to divine magic, and can pinpoint the location of holy symbols, consecrated sites, or divine spells cast within 60 feet of it.

trait.name: Soothing Scent
entries: Creatures within 10 feet of the incense slug are calmed as if by the Calm Emotions spell (both effects). This effect is nonmagical; unwilling creatures must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw to resist. Creatures that lack a sense of smell are unaffected.

action.name: Cnidosac
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1  poison damage.

reaction.name: Healing Mucus {@recharge 4}
entries: When the incense slug takes damage that does not kill it, it can release an oily mucus from its skin, which immediately restores {@dice 1d4} hit points. If this would heal the slug above its HP maximum, the extra healing becomes temporary HP.

All sea slugs are beautiful, mysterious creatures, but this particular species is even more of an enigma than its relatives. Through an unknown method, incense slugs can detect divine magic, and they are instinctively attracted to holy sites and divine casters. They are extremely docile, but have a strong aversion to fiends and fiendish magic.

The pointy cerata covering an incense slug's body exude an oily mucus that smells of sandalwood and citrus. It is not magical, but the scent does encourage calm thoughts and emotions. These cerata can be carefully removed with a sharp knife without injuring the creature, and will grow back within a day. Cerata removed in such a way may be burnt in similar fashion to incense. Alternatively, the oil may be pressed out and used as a soothing balm. It has no medicinal properties, but will ease the discomfort caused by burns, and can also be used as a perfume. Adherents of certain holy orders use this perfume as part of funerary embalming.

Incense slugs are viewed as minor holy creatures by the followers of certain deities, especially those related to fire or the grave. Such holy orders may have special ponds or pools in their temples to house a population of incense slugs.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The vulture has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The vulture has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the vulture's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Quilled Hide
entries: At the start of each of its turns, the porcupine vulture deals 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage to any creature grappling it.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Angled Quills
entries: When it is hit with a melee attack by a creature within 5 feet of it, the porcupine vulture may use its reaction to angle its quills at the attacker. The attacking creature must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage on a failure.

No one is quite sure where porcupine vultures come from. Some say they are the result of experimentation by a dark wizard or twisted druid. Others argue that they are simply a product of nature. Whatever the case, they are to be treated with the same cautious respect that true porcupines deserve. Their spines are just as sharp, and their ability to fly makes it more likely for the unwary traveler to receive a faceful of spines.

trait.name: Grappler
entries: The anemone has advantage on attack rolls against any creature {@condition grappled} by it, and while grappling a creature, it has disadvantage on attack rolls against other creatures.

trait.name: Bioadhesive
entries: The anemone may attach itself to any surface as a free action. A creature must succeed a contested Strength (Athletics) check to pull an anemone free from a surface to which it is attached.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The anemone can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Stingers
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1 piercing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) poison damage.

Flytrap anemones are ambush predators. Relying on their unassuming appearance and ability to attach to any surface, they position themselves in narrow underwater passages where prey will be forced to swim within reach of their tentacles. Once it has detected a potential meal, a flytrap anemone will push off its surface with surprising speed and attempt to enclose its prey in a similar manner to the plant that is its namesake. Tiny flytrap anemones are common on coral reefs and shipwrecks, but they are more of a nuisance than a threat, being too small to consider humanoids worthwhile prey. Small flytrap anemones, on the other hand, might attempt to engulf a limb or wrap around it, and a Medium or Large flytrap anemone might even try to enclose an unlucky person whole!

Even so, a single flytrap anemone is not usually a threat to a party of adventurers. No, the real danger comes when a group must pass through an underwater tunnel or narrow channel. Many such places are lined with tens or hundreds of flytrap anemones of various sizes, all waiting for the slightest disturbance to spring from the walls, floor, and ceiling en masse.

trait.name: Grappler
entries: The anemone has advantage on attack rolls against any creature {@condition grappled} by it, and while grappling a creature, it has disadvantage on attack rolls against other creatures.

trait.name: Bioadhesive

trait.name: Water Breathing

action.name: Stingers
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1 piercing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) poison damage.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 2 piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) poison damage.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 2 piercing damage and 10 ({@damage 3d4 + 3}) poison damage.
