trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The boneworm can breathe air and water.

action.name: Burrow
entries: The boneworm burrows into a creature's flesh. {@atk mw} {@hit +0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1 piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

action.name: Bonemelt
entries: The boneworm attempts to dissolve a portion of the bone it has Implanted in. If it has Implanted in a creature, that creature must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage on a failure. If the boneworm deals a cumulative 1/4 of the creature's maximum HP with Bonemelt, it weakens a bone. The effect of this weakened bone depends on the limb targeted by the initial Implant, and multiple weakened bones have cumulative effects. (If the creature does not have bones, it still takes the acid damage, but is not subject to the effects of weakened bones.)
- Leg: Movement speed is halved (rounding up)
- Both Legs: Movement speed is quartered (rounding down) and cannot take the Dash action
- Arm: Cannot benefit from using a shield, disadvantage on 2-handed or dual-wielding weapon attack rolls
- Both Arms: Cannot benefit from using a shield, disadvantage on attack rolls with a weapon or spell with somatic components
Using {@spell Lesser Restoration} can heal one limb per casting, while a single casting of {@spell Greater Restoration} or {@spell Regenerate} can heal all affected limbs.

bonus.name: Implant
entries: When the boneworm hits a creature with its Burrow attack, it may attempt to dig further into the creature's flesh to access its bones. The target creature must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw to pull the worm off before it Implants. Roll a d4 to determine which limb the worm targets. On a roll of 1 or 2, the worm targets a leg; on a 3 or 4, the worm targets an arm. An Implanted boneworm may be removed by the spell Lesser Restoration, or a successful {@dc 15} Medicine (Wisdom) check.

trait.name: Alluring Scent
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the carrion flower must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the sweet aroma of the flower until the start of its next turn. A creature {@condition charmed} by the carrion flower must use its movement to move as close to the flower as possible. Once it has gotten as close as it can, the creature falls {@condition unconscious}. It cannot regain consciousness by its own action. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the carrion flower's aroma for 24 hours, and they perceive it as a disgusting, rotting smell.

The carrion flower is one of the largest flowers in the known world; specimens have been known to grow in excess of 3 meters tall! They are highly sought after by elite botanists and specialist exhibitions, but great care must be taken when harvesting and displaying these stunning flora, for the carrion flower hides a devious purpose behind its stunning stature.

carrion flowers naturally grow in swamps and large caves, and they are often found with small piles of bones at their bases. These remains are all that is left of their prey, lured in by the sweet, enchanting scent that the flower emits. Once a creature is charmed by the carrion flower, it falls unconscious. Without external help, it will remain at the base of the flower until it, too decomposes, providing fertilizer for the carrion flower and leaving behind another pile of bones.

Some people are able to resist the charming effects of the carrion flower's scent; such individuals universally claim that the flower does not smell sweet and appealing, but rank and rotten. For everyone else wishing to experience the alluring aroma of a carrion flower without becoming its next meal, a select few elite firbolg druids have perfected a technique to remove most of the flower's scent organs, lowering the concentration of the smell to nontoxic levels.

Understandably, these druids are in high demand by the elite botanists and noblemen who desire a carrion flower as a sign of prestige; however, they are exceedingly difficult to contact and extremely selective in their clientele. They also tend to ask for non-traditional forms of payment, such as the cleanup of a city park or the purging of some unnatural beast. Several groups of gnomes and elves are currently attempting to develop a similar technique in order to undercut the druids and reap substantial profit, but they have made little progress. Reports of falling asleep on the job are common.

spellcasting.name: Mesmer
headerEntries: Once per short or long rest, the mesmer octopus can flash lights in a confusing pattern. This pattern has a similar effect to the {@spell Command} spell, with a save DC of 13, no language requirement, and the following differences:
- The only commands it can issue are Approach and Flee

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: While out of water, the octopus can hold its breath for 30 minutes.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The octopus has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The octopus can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Tentacles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 10}). Until this grapple ends, the octopus can't use its tentacles on another target.

action.name: Ink Cloud (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: A 5-foot-radius cloud of ink extends all around the octopus if it is underwater. The area is heavily obscured for 1 minute, although a significant current can disperse the ink. After releasing the ink, the octopus can use the Dash action as a bonus action.

Mesmer octopuses are very similar to the common octopus, but slightly more intelligent and much rarer. They have been known to use the halves of a coconut shell or clam shells as a sort of portable defense and hiding place. They also produce a brilliantly colored pattern of flashing lights along the edge of their tentacles. These flashing lights cause a mesmerizing effect, hence the mesmer octopus' name. Predators and prey are disparately affected by the flashing lights; prey is drawn in a trance toward the octopus, while perceived predators are put in a confused daze that causes them to swim away.
Certain reclusive sea-elf wizards have taken to taming mesmer octopuses as familiars, training them to use their abilities to avoid awkward social interactions or annoying questions.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The jewel wasp can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Jeweled Carapace
entries: The jewel wasp has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks against being seen, unless attempting to hide among gemstones.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the wasp's space. {@h} 1 piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 9} Constitution saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Bite
entries: One creature of the wasp's choice within 5 feet of it must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a success, the attack misses. On a failure, the creature takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage, and the wasp clamps down with its jaws, attaching to the creature and giving the wasp advantage on its Sting attacks against that creature. The jewel wasp stays attached until it decides to let go, or until a creature uses an action to pluck off up to 3 jewel wasps from itself or another creature.

Jewel wasps appear to be large, multicolored wasps that seem to sparkle in bright light. They behave almost identically to normal wasps, apart from the fact that their diet consists entirely of inorganic minerals, with a preference for gemstones and precious metals. They tend to be solitary, but may form eusocial nests if the concentration of gemstones and precious metals is high. Such nests might be found in a dragon's hoard, dwarven mines, or the ruins of ancient opulent temples or palaces.

Through an unknown process, jewel wasps produce a covering of high-quality gemstones over their entire bodies. This "shell" is only present on the main parts of the body; it does not cover the eyes, wings, or legs. Jewel wasps will produce gemstones regardless of their diet, but will do so faster when feeding directly on other gemstones and precious metals.

Because of their unique abilities, jewel wasps are both highly sought after by jewelers, and considered pests by those who store large quantities of treasure. Perhaps as a result of this twofold motivation to kill or capture them, jewel wasps are more aggressive than normal wasps, and their natural instinct is to flee from or attack any humanoid that enters their territory. For this reason, some dragons intentionally keep a nest of jewel wasps with their hoards, apparently deciding that the consumption of a few gems is worth the constant protection. Indeed, these dragons often consider the jewel wasps a part of their collection, seeing their behavior not as destructive, but as the transformation of one treasure into another.

spellcasting.name: Sparkling Gems
headerEntries: Once per long or short rest, while the swarm is in bright light, it can refract the light to cast {@spell Color Spray} at 1st level.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny insect. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Vicious Tactics
entries: At the beginning of each of the swarm's turns, each creature that currently has wasps attached from the effects of Bites is subject to a Stings attack with advantage.

action.name: Stings
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 4d4}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer, this damage changes to 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage and 5 ({@damage 2d4)} poison damage.

action.name: Bites
entries: One creature within 5 feet of the swarm must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 7 ({@damage 3d4}) piercing damage, or half as much damage on a successful save. Additionally, on a failure, 3 wasps clamp down with their mandibles, attaching themselves to the skin or clothing of the target. The wasps remain until they let go, or until the target or another creature uses an action to pluck off up to 3 wasps.

Jewel wasps appear to be large, multicolored wasps that seem to sparkle in bright light. They behave almost identically to normal wasps, apart from the fact that their diet consists entirely of inorganic minerals, with a preference for gemstones and precious metals. They tend to be solitary, but may form eusocial nests if the concentration of gemstones and precious metals is high. Such nests might be found in a dragon's hoard, dwarven mines, or the ruins of ancient opulent temples or palaces.

Through an unknown process, jewel wasps produce a covering of high-quality gemstones over their entire bodies. This "shell" is only present on the main parts of the body; it does not cover the eyes, wings, or legs. Jewel wasps will produce gemstones regardless of their diet, but will do so faster when feeding directly on other gemstones and precious metals.

Because of their unique abilities, jewel wasps are both highly sought after by jewelers, and considered pests by those who store large quantities of treasure. Perhaps as a result of this twofold motivation to kill or capture them, jewel wasps are more aggressive than normal wasps, and their natural instinct is to flee from or attack any humanoid that enters their territory. For this reason, some dragons intentionally keep a nest of jewel wasps with their hoards, apparently deciding that the consumption of a few gems is worth the constant protection. Indeed, these dragons often consider the jewel wasps a part of their collection, seeing their behavior not as destructive, but as the transformation of one treasure into another.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The toxobleps can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Split Eyes
entries: While at the surface of the water, the toxobleps can see above itself in the air and below itself in the water at the same time, and has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks to notice creatures approaching from above or below.

action.name: Poison Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 10/10 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4-1}) poison damage. If the target is a tiny creature that relies on wings for flight, the wings become waterlogged and its flight speed drops to 0 until it can dry its wings.

The toxobleps is a small (~1ft long), relatively unassuming fish with two remarkable traits. First, both its eyes are divided horizontally into two separate pupils, one that faces up and one that faces down. When floating at the surface of the water, these divided eyes allow it to watch the air above it and the water below it at the same time. This not only allows it to watch out for flying and aquatic predators simultaneously, but also sets up its second unique ability: a stream of water laced with poison that it shoots from its mouth. The toxobleps is extremely accurate with this stream, and uses it to hunt insects flying or resting on plants above the water.

The eyes of a toxobleps may be used in potions that grant vision-related effects, such as potions of darkvision or truesight. While darkvision potions are not especially difficult to make, recipes for truesight potions are heavily guarded secrets, and require the toxobleps eyes to be treated with rare reagents in complicated procedures. Toxobleps are also occasionally chosen by certain wizards as familiars. Toxobleps are relatively common, so both of these practices are widespread; however, because of their heightened perception and awareness, catching toxobleps can be a tricky proposition.

trait.name: Bioluminescence
entries: The deepstar emits dim light in a 5-foot radius, and can flash as a free action to briefly emit bright light in a 10-foot radius.

trait.name: Offensive Defense
entries: When a creature touches the giant deepstar or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take 1 piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage. As long as physical contact is sustained, the creature must make this save again at the start of its turn. These effects persist for {@dice 1d4} hours after the giant deepstar dies.

trait.name: Phototaxis
entries: The deepstar is immediately aware of sources of bright light within 500 feet and sources of dim light within 200 feet, if they are not concealed. The deepstar is attracted to sources of light at night, and avoids sources of light during the day.

action.name: Nematocyst
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 1 piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

The result of an unknown wizard's experimentation, giant deepstars are modified to serve as a familiar. Though their name suggests otherwise, giant deepstars are not enormous; they are simply bigger than regular deepstars. While deepstars average between 6-8 inches tall, with outliers reaching over 10 inches, giant deepstars regularly grow over a foot, with the tallest measured at just under 2 feet.

As a result of their increased size, giant deepstars are slightly stronger and slower than normal deepstars, and have lost some of their connection to the Feywild in exchange for a greater anchor to the prime material plane. This has resulted in the loss of their ability to produce spores, but it has also made them much less flammable. Giant deepstars still retain a slight aversion to fire, but they no longer have reason to fear it more than any other creature. As part of their adaptation as familiars, giant deepstars have also been cured of their small range of sight.

Those bonded to a giant deepstar familiar have reported that seeing through the eyes of a deepstar is not as easy as sharing the senses of other familiars. Deepstars have eyes placed at regular intervals in a circle around their bells, and adapting one's mind to properly comprehend a 360-degree field of vision takes effort and practice. Headaches, temporary blindness, and general confusion are common side effects until the deepstar's master becomes mentally experienced with this dramatic shift in perspective.

trait.name: Corpse Collection
entries: As long as the masker has 3 or more Small or Medium corpses attached to its body, its AC is 16, it has resistance to bludgeoning damage, and it has access to the Corpse Drop reaction. The masker also has access to the Corpse Screech action as long as it has at least 1 attached corpse.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The corpse masker makes one Slam attack and one Proboscis attack, then uses Corpse Screech, if available.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Proboscis
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Corpse Screech {@recharge 5}
entries: The masker causes the corpse(s) attached to its body to emit horrifying wails. Each creature within 30 feet of the masker must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage and is {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage and is not {@condition frightened}.

action.name: Attach Corpse
entries: The masker picks up a Small or Medium corpse within 5 feet of it and attaches it to its body. The masker can have up to 3 corpses attached to it, where a Medium corpse counts as 1 and a Small corpse counts as 1/2.

reaction.name: Corpse Drop
entries: When the masker becomes {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}, it may use its reaction to release all the corpses currently attached to its body (requires at least 3 attached corpses) to immediately end the {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained} condition. This does not prevent either condition from being reapplied.

An enormous insect scurries toward the band of waiting adventurers. As it nears, they notice dead bodies attached to its abdomen, their lost companion among them. Suddenly, their companion and the other corpses open their mouths, and piercing wails of pain split the tense silence. There is a moment of quiet as the creature continues to charge, then the adventurers turn and flee, their minds corrupted with fear.

The corpse masker is a terrifying beast, with even more terrible habits. Appearing as a giant assassin bug, the corpse masker feeds on any creature it can catch, piercing them with its proboscis and digesting their innards with toxic enzymes. It enhances its natural armor (and fear factor) by attaching the desiccated corpses of its prey to its carapace. Through unknown cursed magic, it has the awful ability to cause these corpses to scream in awful agony, striking terror into the minds of those who hear it.

trait.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: The ancalag has advantage on saving throws against breath weapons.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The ancalag can breathe air and water.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage.

bonus.name: Embed
entries: When the ancalag hits a target with a bite attack, it may use its bonus action to attempt to grapple the target. It has advantage on the grapple attack roll if the target is surprised or {@condition incapacitated}. If it succeeds, the target must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the ancalag infests the target (see this creature's description for the effects of infestation). On a success, the ancalag is unable to infest the target, and rapidly deteriorates, causing the target to take 27 ({@damage 5d10}) necrotic damage as it releases its body fluids inside the target. Adult and ancient dragons immediately succeed this saving throw, as do aberrations, constructs, elementals, oozes, plants, and creatures above CR 12.

Sounds of a rampaging dragon have been heard in the countryside for days. The locals sent word to the city, which has dispatched a team of adventurers to investigate. As the adventurers close in on the lair, they begin to notice a nauseating, putrid stench in the air. There is the sound of a dragon roar, oddly wet and gurgling. Suddenly, the ground shakes, and something bursts from the cave entrance. It is a dragon, but something is dreadfully wrong. All color has drained from its scales, its eyes are sunken in its skull, and there are large, seeping holes in its flesh. The rogue stealthily approaches from behind, but right when she moves to strike, she is caught off guard by a pink flash of movement. Out of one of its oozing wounds, a fleshy worm with rings of razor-sharp teeth lashes out, ripping through the rogue's armor and tearing her forearm to shreds. It is only then that the party notices the wriggling underneath the dragon's skin. This dragon has fallen victim to an ancalag infestation.

When found in the wild, ancalags are tiny, pathetic-looking pink worms. Their rings of teeth look mildly threatening, but few people realize how dangerous these parasites really are. Specialized to infest dragons, the fleshy form of an ancalag belies its incredible strength and resilience. Moreover, ancalags rarely attack alone. They hide in caves, sewers, and other out-of-the-way places, infecting any creatures they can, then compelling their hosts to seek out their true target: dragons.

The effects of ancalag infestation depend on the host. More than one may infest a host, in which case effects are cumulative, and surgically removing multiple ancalags requires a separate Dexterity check for each one. Aside from {@spell Wish}, all magical methods of curing ancalag infestation deal half the necrotic damage associated with a failed surgical Dexterity check, per ancalag (27 ({@damage 5d10}) for dragons or 11 ({@damage 2d10}) for others).

- If the host is not a true dragon, it becomes compelled to seek out true dragons, though this confers no special ability to find dragons. The creature behaves as it normally would, except that its primary goal is to find a true dragon. Ancalag infestation also reduces the maximum hit points of the host by 5 ({@dice 2d4}).

The infestation can be cured by {@spell Greater Restoration} or more powerful healing magic. The ancalag may also be removed surgically by a professional surgeon, requiring a DC 25 Wisdom (Medicine) check to extract the ancalag, and a DC 25 Dexterity check to avoid releasing the ancalag's bodily fluids into the host, which deals 22 ({@damage 4d10}) necrotic damage. This surgery takes {@dice 1d4+1} hours, and regardless of the result, leaves the subject incapacitated for {@dice 1d4+3} days. The creature must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom to take any action that would lead toward curing the infestation.

- If the host is a wyrmling or young dragon, it begins the transformation into an infested wyrmling or young dragon, whose information can be found in this document. This transformation takes 1 year, after which the infestation is incurable.

Ancalags feed on the innate magic of these dragons, which makes them almost impossible to successfully remove from a dragon host. Only {@spell Mass Heal}, {@spell Power Word Heal}, or {@spell Wish} can cure such an infection, or {@spell Regenerate} cast every hour for 24 hours. Alternatively, surgically removing an ancalag from a dragon requires an experienced professional surgeon, adamantine surgical tools, and a DC 30 Wisdom (Medicine) check. The surgeon must also succeed on a DC 30 Dexterity check to avoid releasing the ancalag's bodily fluids into the dragon, which deals 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage. Such a surgery takes {@dice 1d6+2} hours, and leaves the dragon incapacitated for {@dice 1d4+1} weeks.

- If the host is an adult or ancient dragon, the infestation fails, as the immense magical power of these dragons overwhelms the ancalag. Other immensely powerful creatures (CR >12) are generally immune to ancalag infestation. Ancalags are also incapable of infesting aberrations, constructs, elementals, oozes, or plants.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The dragon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the infested dragon wyrmling to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the infested dragon wyrmling drops to 1 hit point instead. On a failure, {@dice 1d4 + 2} ancalags burst from the corpse, making immediate bite attacks at any creature within 10 feet of the dragon (see the ancalag stat block).

trait.name: Worm Infestation
entries: The dragon may make any number of opportunity attacks without expending its reaction. If it does not use its reaction for an opportunity attack, the attack may only be a worm lunge attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Worm Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Rotting Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales putrid gas in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Each creature must also make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, becoming {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn on a failed save.

Sounds of a rampaging dragon have been heard in the countryside for days. The locals sent word to the city, which has dispatched a team of adventurers to investigate. As the adventurers close in on the lair, they begin to notice a nauseating, putrid stench in the air. There is the sound of a dragon roar, oddly wet and gurgling. Suddenly, the ground shakes, and something bursts from the cave entrance. It is a dragon, but something is dreadfully wrong. All color has drained from its scales, its eyes are sunken in its skull, and there are large, seeping holes in its flesh. The rogue stealthily approaches from behind, but right when she moves to strike, she is caught off guard by a pink flash of movement. Out of one of its oozing wounds, a fleshy worm with rings of razor-sharp teeth lashes out, ripping through the rogue's armor and tearing her forearm to shreds. It is only then that the party notices the wriggling underneath the dragon's skin. This dragon has fallen victim to an ancalag infestation.

Only wyrmlings and young dragons can naturally be infested by ancalags. The potent magic of an adult or ancient dragon is too powerful for the parasites to survive under normal circumstances. Occasionally, however, a cult worshipping a deity of disease or some other corrupting influence will perform a ritual to weaken an adult dragon, allowing it to be infested by ancalags, and forming a disgusting force of reckoning. These rituals, powerful as they may be, are still incapable of weakening an ancient dragon; an infested ancient dragon is only ever created through the direct action of a deity, archdevil, or similarly powerful force. These creatures are practically avatars of disease and corruption.

Infested dragons of any age speak rarely and with difficulty. When they do speak, it is with a wet, rasping gurgle. Since it is not really the dragon speaking, but the colony of ancalags inside speaking through the dragon's mouth, infested dragons refer to themselves in the third person, and may talk with multiple voices, interrupting each other or echoing speech, as if many creatures were speaking at once.

When found in the wild, ancalags are tiny, pathetic-looking pink worms. Their rings of teeth look mildly threatening, but few people realize how dangerous these parasites really are. Specialized to infest dragons, the fleshy form of an ancalag belies its incredible strength and resilience. Moreover, ancalags rarely attack alone. They hide in caves, sewers, and other out-of-the-way places, infecting any creatures they can, then compelling their hosts to seek out their true target: dragons.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The dragon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the infested young dragon to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the infested young dragon drops to 1 hit point instead. On a failure, {@dice 1d8 + 4} ancalags burst from the corpse, making immediate bite attacks at any creature within 10 feet of the dragon (see the ancalag stat block).

trait.name: Worm Infestation
entries: The dragon may make any number of opportunity attacks without expending its reaction. If it does not use its reaction for an opportunity attack, the attack may only be a worm lunge attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Worm Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Rotting Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales putrid gas in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 49 ({@damage 11d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Each creature must also make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, becoming {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn on a failed save.

Sounds of a rampaging dragon have been heard in the countryside for days. The locals sent word to the city, which has dispatched a team of adventurers to investigate. As the adventurers close in on the lair, they begin to notice a nauseating, putrid stench in the air. There is the sound of a dragon roar, oddly wet and gurgling. Suddenly, the ground shakes, and something bursts from the cave entrance. It is a dragon, but something is dreadfully wrong. All color has drained from its scales, its eyes are sunken in its skull, and there are large, seeping holes in its flesh. The rogue stealthily approaches from behind, but right when she moves to strike, she is caught off guard by a pink flash of movement. Out of one of its oozing wounds, a fleshy worm with rings of razor-sharp teeth lashes out, ripping through the rogue's armor and tearing her forearm to shreds. It is only then that the party notices the wriggling underneath the dragon's skin. This dragon has fallen victim to an ancalag infestation.

Occasionally, however, a cult worshipping a deity of disease or some other corrupting influence will perform a ritual to weaken an adult dragon, allowing it to be infested by ancalags, and forming a disgusting force of reckoning. These rituals, powerful as they may be, are still incapable of weakening an ancient dragon; an infested ancient dragon is only ever created through the direct action of a deity, archdevil, or similarly powerful force. These creatures are practically avatars of disease and corruption.

Infested dragons of any age speak rarely and with difficulty. When they do speak, it is with a wet, rasping gurgle. Since it is not really the dragon speaking, but the colony of ancalags inside speaking through the dragon's mouth, infested dragons refer to themselves in the third person, and may talk with multiple voices, interrupting each other or echoing speech, as if many creatures were speaking at once.

Specialized to infest dragons, the fleshy form of an ancalag belies its incredible strength and resilience. Moreover, ancalags rarely attack alone. They hide in caves, sewers, and other out-of-the-way places, infecting any creatures they can, then compelling their hosts to seek out their true target: dragons.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The glass squid can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the glass squid remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an inanimate glass statue.

trait.name: Photophores
entries: The glass squid may flash small dots of light across its skin in various patterns, producing an aesthetically pleasing display and causing the squid to emit bright light in its space.

action.name: Hooked Tentacles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage and 1 slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 10}). Until this grapple ends, the squid can't use its tentacles on another target.

action.name: Ink Cloud (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: A 5-foot-radius cloud of ink extends all around the squid if it is underwater. The area is heavily obscured for 1 minute, although a significant current can disperse the ink. After releasing the ink, the squid can use the Dash action as a bonus action.

Glass squid are dazzling creatures, prized as ornamental pets by the royalty of many underwater peoples. Their transparent bodies and hard but brittle skin cause them to appear as intricate, living glass sculptures. Moreover, they are capable of producing incredible patterns of flashing light, which are universally considered extraordinarily beautiful by those lucky enough to witness such a performance. They are unfortunately very fragile, and their owners tend to visit harsh consequences on those who harm a glass squid.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

bonus.name: Electrified Scales
entries: The gecko sends a surge of electricity through its scales, dealing 1 lightning damage to any creature touching it.
Lightning geckos are similar to regular lizards, except that they are extremely rare, have bright blue scales, and can generate a painful shock when handled.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The anomalocaris can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Temporal Sense
entries: The anomalocaris can sense magic or other effects that alter the flow of time within 60 feet of itself. Most anomalocaris are attracted to such phenomena.

trait.name: Grappler
entries: The anomalocaris has advantage on attack rolls against any creature {@condition grappled} by it.

action.name: Endite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}0 ({@damage 1}) piercing damage. If the target is a Small or smaller creature, it must make a {@dc 13} Strength or Dexterity saving throw, becoming {@condition grappled} on a failure. While grappling a creature, the anomalocaris cannot use its Endite attack on any creature except the one it is grappling.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target {@condition grappled} by the anomalocaris. {@h}1 ({@damage 1}) slashing damage.

variant.name: Anomalocaris Familiars
entries: When a wizard takes an anomalocaris as a familiar, they usually apply minor enchantments to the creature to allow it to function outside of water. These enchantments are performed as a modification of the {@spell Find Familiar} spell, and give the anomalocaris the Amphibious trait and a fly (hover) speed of 30 feet.

Anomalocaris is an extinct sea creature from the primordial past, an ancient predatory beast measuring between one and three feet long. The two spined appendages at the front of their bodies are used for grappling prey, holding it still long enough to take a bite with their odd circular tooth plates. They swim with a graceful, undulating motion that belies their speed.

Anomalocaris are known to modern scholars only because one occasionally slips through a fault in the chaos of planar separation, ending up at a random spot in time. Why these animals in particular have an affinity for finding such temporal cracks remains unclear. Divination wizards seeking to show off sometimes take these creatures as familiars, since the precision necessary to predict when and where an anomalocaris will appear requires an impressive mastery of all manners of divining, including scrying, dreaming, and augury. More than just a status symbol, anomalocaris are also useful at searching out temporal anomalies that are often of interest to such wizards. These wizards usually apply minor enchantments to the anomalocaris, allowing it to move and survive outside of water. These enchantments are applied as modifications to the {@spell Find Familiar} spell.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The giant incense slug can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Divine Sense
entries: The giant incense slug is attracted to divine magic, and can pinpoint the location of holy symbols, consecrated sites, or divine spells cast within 300 feet of it.

trait.name: Soothing Scent
entries: Creatures within 30 feet of the giant incense slug are calmed as if by the Calm Emotions spell (both effects). This effect is nonmagical; unwilling creatures must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw to resist. Creatures that lack a sense of smell are unaffected.

trait.name: Incense Cerata
entries: If the giant incense slug takes fire damage, the effects of Soothing Scent extend to 60 feet for 1 minute.

action.name: Cerata
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) bludgeoning damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Cnidosac
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Healing Mucus {@recharge 4}
entries: The giant incense slug excretes an oily, soothing mucus onto one creature within 5 feet of it. That creature regains {@dice 1d10} hit points, unless it is undead, in which case it takes {@damage 1d10} radiant damage. An unwilling creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw to avoid this effect.

reaction.name: Protective Mucus {@recharge 3}
entries: When the incense slug takes damage that does not kill it, it can release an oily mucus from its skin, which immediately restores {@dice 2d10} hit points. If this would heal the slug above its HP maximum, the extra healing becomes temporary HP, which lasts until the end of the slug's next turn.

If the slug is underwater, the excess mucus spreads into the water around it, healing all creatures in spaces adjacent to the giant incense slug, with the exception of undead, which instead take {@damage 1d10} radiant damage.

Unlike other giant slugs, which can be encountered in the wild and whose origins are a mystery, giant incense slugs are almost always found in large temples or other sacred areas of good-aligned deities, and they arise exclusively from holy rituals. Most temples hold these rituals as closely-guarded secrets, believing the creation of a giant incense slug to be a sacred act, reserved for high priests and conducted in inner sanctums.

Outside of the upper-echelon of priests, knowledge of giant incense slugs is almost nonexistent. One may occasionally hear a rumor of a magical beast dwelling in the depths of a temple, or hidden away at secret holy sites, but even the most credible of these tales contains mere scraps of truth. An adventuring party might stumble upon one if they happen to explore an abandoned temple or the sacred ground of an ancient religion. In such cases, the giant incense slug may have lived in the ruins for decades or centuries, continuing its duty of consecrating the area, protecting relics, and most importantly, warding off the undead.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The gasflame slug can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Flammable
entries: If the gasflame slug takes fire damage, the gas leaking out of the tips of its cerata catch fire. The damage type for its cnidosac attack becomes fire instead of poison, and the slug gains the Heated Body trait. This effect lasts until the end of the slug's next turn, and cannot be activated again until the slug completes a long or short rest.

trait.name: Heated Body (activated by Flammable)
entries: A creature that touches the gasflame slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage.

action.name: Gas Jet
entries: The gasflame slug expels a puff of gas at a creature within 5 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, taking 1 poison damage on a failure.

action.name: Toxic Gas {@recharge 4}
entries: The gasflame slug pumps a poisonous, flammable gas into the area around it. Creatures within 5 feet of the slug must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, becoming {@condition poisoned} on a failure. Affected creatures also have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

The gas lingers until the end of the slug's next turn. During this time, any creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of the gasflame slug must make the associated Constitution saving throw. Additionally for the duration, if any source of fire, magical or nonmagical, comes within 5 feet of the slug, the gas ignites, dealing {@damage 1d4} fire damage to the slug and all creatures within 5 feet of it.

Traveling through a swamp, the merchant spots a beautiful creature on the trunk of a nearby tree. Its body is almost transparent, covered in small tentacles tipped with brilliant shades of blue and orange. He lights a torch in order to get a better look, and as he peers toward the creature, a sudden explosion singes off his eyebrows and sends the torch flying!

Gasflame slugs can be found in swamps, sewers, and other places with an abundance of decomposing matter. They feed primarily on rotting wood and plants, but will happily consume any sewage. As a byproduct of digesting such sustenance, the slugs slowly produce a foul-smelling gas, which leaks out of the tips of their cerata. This gas is both toxic and flammable, and the slugs use it as a defense mechanism, pumping out clouds of the rancid fumes when startled. Unsurprisingly, scholars who study gasflame slugs are characterized by singed eyebrows and dulled sense of smell. Such scholars are usually artificers and tinkerers, seeking to harness the potential of such highly flammable gas for their contraptions.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The gasflame slug can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Flammable
entries: If the gasflame slug takes fire damage, the gas leaking out of the tips of its cerata catch fire. The effects of its gas jet attack and Toxic Gas change as described, and the slug gains the Heated Body trait. This effect lasts for 1 minute, after which it cannot be activated again until the slug completes a long or short rest.

trait.name: Heated Body (activated by Flammable)
entries: A creature that touches the gasflame slug or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage.

action.name: Gas Jet
entries: The slug launches a jet of pressurized gas at one creature it can see within 15 feet of itself. The creature must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. If there is a source of fire within 5 feet of the target, or if a source of fire enters within 5 feet of the target before it moves at least 10 feet, the lingering gas explodes, dealing 4 ({@damage 1d8}) fire damage to the target and any creature within 5 feet of it.
If the slug's Flammable trait has been activated, this attack instead deals 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failure, or half as much on a success, and there are no lingering effects.

action.name: Toxic Gas {@recharge 4}
entries: The gasflame slug pumps a poisonous, flammable gas into the area around it. Creatures within 5 feet of the slug must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, creatures are {@condition poisoned} and have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell until the end of their next turn.

The gas continues flowing until the end of the slug's next turn. During this time, any creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of the gasflame slug must make the associated Constitution saving throw. Additionally for the duration, if any source of fire comes within 5 feet of the slug, the gas ignites, dealing 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage to the slug and all creatures within 5 feet of it.

If the slug's Flammable trait has been activated, this action instead requires a creatures within 5 feet to make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, dealing 16 ({@damage 3d10}) fire damage on a failure, or half as much on a success, with no lingering effects.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 9} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 9} Constitution saving throw, taking 4 ({@damage 1d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

As if spiders and scorpions weren't bad enough, someone had to go and make a spider with a scorpion tail. Because of the time it takes to replenish venom, the scorpion-tailed spider tends to alternate between its bite and sting attacks.

bonus.name: Toxic Secretion {@recharge 3}
entries: The giant millipede releases a foul-smelling orange liquid from its pores. Until the end of its next turn, creatures that touch the millipede or hit it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. Also on a failure, roll a {@dice 1d100}. If a 1 is rolled, the creature becomes {@condition blinded} until cured by {@spell Lesser Restoration} or a similar effect.

reaction.name: Defensive Roll
entries: When the giant millipede takes damage from an attack, or is {@condition frightened} or {@condition surprised}, it can curl up into a defensive posture, hiding its more vulnerable underbelly. It may hold this position for up to an hour. Until it uncurls as an action, the giant millipede is subject to the following effects:
- its movement speed drops to 0
- it is {@condition prone}
- it has a +1 bonus to its AC
- it has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks
- it has advantage on Charisma (Performance) checks made to convince another creature that it is dead

Giant millipedes, though larger than giant centipedes, are much less threatening than their aggressive cousins. While centipedes are predators, millipedes, even the giant ones, are docile herbivores, feeding on moss and rotting leaves. They do not have a venomous bite like centipedes do; in fact, they do not generally bite anything but plants.

However, giant millipedes are not totally helpless. When threatened, they can curl up into a tight spiral, hiding their vulnerable undersides and remaining completely still until the threat has passed. If that isn't enough to discourage an attacker, millipedes also excrete a foul-smelling poison from their skin. The poison is dark orange in color, and causes a variety of unpleasant effects, including:
- blistering
- itching and burning sensations
- temporary orange staining of skin
- nausea and vomiting (if ingested)
The toxin has additional nasty effects if a creature happens to get it in their eyes:
- eye spasms
- excessive tear production
- temporary blindness (rarely)

Due to their passive nature and natural climbing ability, giant millipedes are occasionally used as mounts by forest gnomes and some fey. Generally, the saddles used for riding giant millipedes have straps to secure the rider, since the creatures have a habit of crawling upside-down on the underside of large tree branches.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the pelican flower remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an (unusual) ordinary flower.

action.name: Gulp
entries: The pelican flower attempts to swallow one Tiny creature in an adjacent space. The target must make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw (or {@dc 13} if the target is surprised by the flower). On a failure, the pelican flower successfully entraps the target in its digestive chamber, dealing 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage to it. The creature takes this damage again at the end of each of its turns. A swallowed creature can escape by dealing a total of 2 damage to the flower, in which case it appears in a space adjacent to the pelican flower, falling to the ground {@condition prone}.

The large opening, pitcher-shaped sac, and smell of the pelican flower mark it as a carnivorous plant. However, unlike flytraps or pitcher plants, this one has a bit more agency. Using the two enormous flaps on either side of its feeding hole, a pelican flower can fly, appearing somewhat like a giant, clumsy butterfly. It uses this ability to swoop down on unsuspecting prey, relying on potent digestive acids to dissolve food before it has a chance to fight back.

Fortunately, though they are much larger than most blooms, pelican flowers are too small to target anything bigger than a housecat. Their normal prey are small rodents and reptiles, which they attract with a sweet, honey-like fragrance. When not actively feeding, pelican flowers attach themselves to trees, vines, and other plants, attempting to blend in with the flora until suitable prey wanders too close.

Pelican flowers are uncommon, tending to grow in places not frequented by people. Gardeners occasionally seek them out for use as natural pest control, but this is a tricky endeavor. Since the flowers are not intelligent enough to be trained, they often end up eating a pet or two before the gardener in question realizes the problem and gets rid of them. Druids and tribal shamans sometimes maintain a population of pelican flowers for medicinal use; their digestive acids, when diluted, are very effective at reducing itching, irritation, and pain associated with bug bites and stings, poisonous plants, and other minor inconveniences. In more concentrated solutions, the acids can be used to dissolve organic matter. One flower provides one vial of digestive acid, which functions in combat like a regular vial of acid, except that it deals 2 ({@dice 1d4}) acid damage on hit and at the start of the target's turns, until a creature uses an action to wipe off the acid. Out of combat, one vial takes 1 minute to dissolve an area of animal or plant matter no larger than 6 inches on a side. 15 vials will dissolve 1 cubic foot of flesh or plant matter in about 10 minutes, while dissolving the same amount of bone takes roughly an hour.
To dissolve an entire creature, the {@bold approximate} amount of acid needed is as follows:
- Tiny creature: 1 vial to dissolve flesh in 1 minute. Additional vial to dissolve skeleton in 3 minutes
- Small creature: 8 vials to dissolve flesh in 5 minutes. Additional 3 vials to dissolve skeleton in 15 minutes.
- Medium creature: 30 vials to dissolve flesh in 20 minutes. Additional 10 vials to dissolve skeleton in 30 minutes.
- Large creature: 200 vials to dissolve flesh in 3 hours. Additional 60 vials to dissolve skeleton in 4 hours.

It is nearly impossible to find enough flowers by foraging to dissolve anything larger than a single Medium creature, since there are never very many pelican flowers in a single area. Acid on these quantities must be purchased from someone who cultivates pelican flowers and harvests the digestive acid.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The stareater can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Light Absorption
entries: Whenever the stareater is subjected to radiant damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the radiant damage dealt.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Aphosis
entries: The stareater attempts to consume a source of light within 5 feet of itself. The light source is automatically extinguished if:
- it is not being worn or carried by a creature
- it is not a magic item
- it is not larger than 1 foot on a side

If the light source is being worn or carried by a creature, the creature must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, avoiding the effect on a success, or being subject to the effect as normal on a failure.

If the light source is a magical item activated by expending charges, it may be reactivated by using the appropriate number of charges; otherwise, the item loses its ability to shed light for 1 minute.
If the light source is larger than 1 foot on a side, a spherical portion of the light source 1 foot in diameter ceases to shed light, following all previous rules.
If the light source is a spell, it is affected as follows:
- The {@spell Light} cantrip is extinguished, regardless of the size of the object.
- A light created by {@spell Dancing Lights} is extinguished, but other lights created by the spell are not affected.
- The effects of {@spell Faerie Fire} end for the target creature

- The area created by {@spell Daylight} is treated as a light source larger than 1 foot on a side, and each activation of this ability darkens a 1 foot diameter sphere within the area, unless the spell was cast targeting a specific object, in which case the object is treated as the source of light. If the object is smaller than 1 foot on a side, it is extinguished and the spell ends; if the object is larger than 1 foot on a side, it is treated as a light source of the appropriate size, and the spell ends once its entire surface has been affected.
- A {@spell Wall of Light} is unaffected by this ability.
- Other spells that create a light source may be partially or fully extinguished by this ability, but any other effects of the spell are unaffected.

bonus.name: Nova
entries: When the stareater successfully uses Aphosis, it may use its bonus action to trigger one of the following effects:
- the stareater regains 2 ({@dice 1d4}) hit points.

- all creatures that can see the stareater within 20 feet of it must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, as the stareater releases a searing flash of light. A creature that fails the saving throw is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. Other stareaters and astronesths are immune to this effect.

- the stareater flashes an entrancing pattern of lights. One creature of its choice within 15 feet of it must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw, becoming {@condition charmed} until the end of its next turn on a failure.

Stareaters are large (~3 ft.), sleek, streamlined fish, with pitch-black scales and a row of light organs running down either side of their bodies. While this appearance alone is remarkable, it is their hunting behavior that makes them truly unique. Their long, thin, semi-translucent teeth indicate that they might eat smaller fish, but this is far from the truth. In fact, stareaters, as their name, suggests, consume light itself.

Few trustworthy descriptions of stareaters exist. Most eyewitness accounts describe a black streak in the water, a splash, and then darkness. As if they weren't already difficult enough to spot, stareaters only venture into shallow water on nights when the moon is not visible. At all other times, they live in the depths, beyond where sunlight penetrates, subsisting on the glow of bioluminescent bacteria and other flashing critters. But on moonless nights, they surface, seeking the lamps of boats and fishermen. The lucky ones might even find an adventuring party, with all sorts of magical lights to feast upon.

Stareaters are not inherently aggressive; while they will pursue bright sources of light with reckless abandon, they are unlikely to intentionally attack or harm creatures larger than themselves. Schools of trained stareaters are sometimes used by the aquatic races as a first line of defense to hide valuable secrets from prying eyes without resorting to violence.
A stareater that has gorged itself on magic light can mutate into an astronesth.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The dragon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the dragon to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the dragon drops to 1 hit point instead. On a failure, {@dice 1d12 + 7} ancalags burst from the corpse, making immediate bite attacks at any creature within 10 feet of the dragon (see the ancalag stat block).

trait.name: Worm Infestation
entries: The dragon may make any number of opportunity attacks without expending its reaction. If it does not use its reaction for an opportunity attack, the attack may only be a worm lunge attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Worm Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d12}) piercing damage and 6 ({@damage 1d12}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Rotting Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales putrid gas in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 58 ({@damage 13d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Each creature must also make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw, becoming {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn on a failed save.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 10 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or take 14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

Sounds of a rampaging dragon have been heard in the countryside for days. The locals sent word to the city, which has dispatched a team of adventurers to investigate. As the adventurers close in on the lair, they begin to notice a nauseating, putrid stench in the air. There is the sound of a dragon roar, oddly wet and gurgling. Suddenly, the ground shakes, and something bursts from the cave entrance. It is a dragon, but something is dreadfully wrong. All color has drained from its scales, its eyes are sunken in its skull, and there are large, seeping holes in its flesh. The rogue stealthily approaches from behind, but right when she moves to strike, she is caught off guard by a pink flash of movement. Out of one of its oozing wounds, a fleshy worm with rings of razor-sharp teeth lashes out, ripping through the rogue's armor and tearing her forearm to shreds. It is only then that the party notices the wriggling underneath the dragon's skin. This dragon has fallen victim to an ancalag infestation.

Only wyrmlings and young dragons can naturally be infested by ancalags. The potent magic of an adult or ancient dragon is too powerful for the parasites to survive under normal circumstances. Occasionally, however, a cult worshipping a deity of disease or some other corrupting influence will perform a ritual to weaken an adult dragon, allowing it to be infested by ancalags, and forming a disgusting force of reckoning. These rituals, powerful as they may be, are still incapable of weakening an ancient dragon; an infested ancient dragon is only ever created through the direct action of a deity, archdevil, or similarly powerful force. These creatures are practically avatars of disease and corruption.

Infested dragons of any age speak rarely and with difficulty. When they do speak, it is with a wet, rasping gurgle. Since it is not really the dragon speaking, but the colony of ancalags inside speaking through the dragon's mouth, infested dragons refer to themselves in the third person, and may talk with multiple voices, interrupting each other or echoing speech, as if many creatures were speaking at once.

An infested adult or ancient dragon will inhabit the same lair that it did before it was infested, but it makes noticeable changes to the surrounding area. The existing regional effects fade as if the dragon were dead, and the infested dragon makes every effort to make it appear as though the lair is abandoned. Aside from the abundant worms burrowing throughout the area, there are few cues that a dragon still resides in the lair. In this way, the infested dragon hopes to lure a young dragon with the temptation of a pre-established lair and territory. When a young dragon falls for the trap, it finds not a welcoming, abandoned lair, but only an ambush of ancalags, waiting to infest another host.

When found in the wild, ancalags are tiny, pathetic-looking pink worms. Their rings of teeth look mildly threatening, but few people realize how dangerous these parasites really are. Specialized to infest dragons, the fleshy form of an ancalag belies its incredible strength and resilience. Moreover, ancalags rarely attack alone. They hide in caves, sewers, and other out-of-the-way places, infecting any creatures they can, then compelling their hosts to seek out their true target: dragons.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The dragon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the dragon to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the dragon drops to 1 hit point instead. On a failure, {@dice 1d20 + 10} ancalags burst from the corpse, making immediate bite attacks at any creature within 10 feet of the dragon (see the ancalag stat block).

trait.name: Worm Infestation
entries: The dragon may make any number of opportunity attacks without expending its reaction. If it does not use its reaction for an opportunity attack, the attack may only be a worm lunge attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 2d10 + 9}) piercing damage plus 6 ({@damage 1d12}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d6 + 9}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d8 + 9}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Worm Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage and 8 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Rotting Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales putrid gas in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 23} Dexterity saving throw, taking 76 ({@damage 17d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Each creature must also make a {@dc 23} Constitution saving throw, becoming {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn on a failed save.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 10 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 2d6 + 9}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

These creatures are practically avatars of disease and corruption.

Since it is not really the dragon speaking, but the colony of ancalags inside speaking through the dragon's mouth, infested dragons refer to themselves in the third person, and may talk with multiple voices, interrupting each other or echoing speech, as if many creatures were speaking at once.
